div.head: ISLAM IN INDIA.
div.p: Mobamedanism is still a great force in India It is the faith of one person out of every five in the country, write* Mr. Sidney Low in ''The Standard." The King rules more than half the Mohamedan population of the world, the Sultan of Turkey coming a very long way behind him. There is one province—that of the North-West Frontier—which is almost entirely Mohamedan, the Hindus being an unimportant minority. In the Punjab Mohamedans an numerous, and they are to be found scattered everywhere down to the extreme sooth, especially in the towns. In Eastern Bengal there are some twenty-eight millions of them, and here they increase more rapidly than the Hindus; for the Mussulman, with his varied diet, has a better physique than the pulse and grain-feeding Brahmanists, and, moreover, be does not believe in child marriages, nor does he think it wrong for widows to re-marry. The high and growing proportion of the Mohamedan population in Bengal is one of the hard nuts for the Bengalis to crack. It is also an elementary fact which is not generally appreciated. By race these Bengal Mohamedans are akin to the Hindus, and that, indeed, is true of the great majority of their co-religionists outside the Frontier province. Most of them are descended from Hindus who were converted daring the long period of Moslem role. They exist as a standing argument against the modern doctrine which ascribes everything to race, and nothing to environment, education, social conditions, and custom. Islam has developed the character of the Indian Mohamedan somewhat at the expense of hi* intellect He is simpler, braver, more mas-online, more devout, in a rough, practical, straightforward fashion, hot he is less subtle, less ingenious, less acute, and far less capable of assimilating the methods of modern educa-tion. He makes a first-rate soldier, a good policeman, inspector, or watchman, and be does fairly well in any post when courage, fidelity, and a certain self respect and requisite he has a distinct aptitude for trade, and as a shopkeeper be is frequently very successful. He is a convenient man to bare a butler or personal servant, for in the tint place be is in moderation honest, and secondly, he is not under the tyranny of caste rules, and can serve food to a Christian without a qualm. Bat the Hindu beats him at the office and the desk, and in the class-room. This is one of the reasons why there ought not to be direct appointments to the higher Civil Service by competitive examination in India. It is quite certain that in this contest the babu and the Brahman would beat the Mohamedan out of the field. Most Indian Mussulmans cherish in their hearts some memory of the days when their fathers were the masters of India, and they believe that, if ever the English power were shaken, they would regain their old predominance. In the meanwhile the Mohamedans will endure being the subjects of a Christian race, whose character they respect, and whose religion they can understand. But to The feebler tribes of idol-worshippers, as they consider them, they protest indignantly that it would be an outrage to ask them to yield obedience.

div.head: The Plague
div.p: Another case of plague is reported from Keneh.

div.head: Cairo French Hospital-
div.p: Mme. Beyerlé has presented the French Hospital in Cairo with £200 for the endowment of a bed in memory of her late husband.

div.head: Ethel Pain Memorial Hospital.
div.p: The Earl and Countess of Meath will inspect the new building of the Ethel Pain Memorial Hospital at Old Cairo on Saturday, 14th inst.

div.head: Excelsiorl
div.p: Rumours are afloat that the projected hotel opposite the Savoy will be called the Excelsior. Let us hope it will belie its name. We have enough sky-scrapers in Cairo and the sun is our best disinfectant.

div.head: Weather in Upper Egypt.
div.p: Our Luxor Correspondent telegraphs that the temperature at Luxor on Saturday at 9 а. m. was 66 deg. and at noon 73 deg. Fahrenheit, which is remarkably cool for the time of year.

div.head: University for Alexandria.
div.p: The Council of Ministers has decided to grant a large plot of Government land - 24,000 metres in area—situated at Gabbari, to the Alexandria Ulema Board, for the purpose of building a large religious university.

div.head: Charge of Assault.
div.p: This morning, Spiro Ellul was brought up at the British Consular Court, Cairo, on a charge of wounding Raffaele Grech Cumbo on Saturday, 31st ulto. The proceedings were not concluded at the time our reporter telephoned.

div.head: Hashish Seizure.
div.p: The Coast Guards seized 67 kilos of hashish as the drug was being lowered from a boat in Alexandria harbour on Saturday. The weight of the hashish which was discovered by them in the eastern harbour, as reported in oar last issue, was no less than 1,045 kilos.

div.head: Wilson Pacha's Will.
div.p: Mr. James Wilson (Wilson Pacha), of 19, Lymington-road, Hampstead, and formerly of Cairo, who died on February 24, left estate valued at £20,141 15s. gross, in the United Kingdom, the net personalty being sworn at £19,872 4s. 7d. Probate of his will dated March 22, 1881, has been granted to his widow, Mrs. Annie Wilson, of 19, Lymington- road, to whom he left the whole of his estate absolutely.

div.head: Luncheon on the Pyramids.
div.p: Moonlight parties to Mena House Hotel are as popular as ever, not with standing that there has been a great exodus from Cairo. Mr. Sloman and a party were quite early at Mena House Hotel on Saturday. Mr. Sloman had invited some friends to climb the Pyramids. The party went up accompanied by a crowd of servants, who Carried luncheon baskets and wine cases, and had lunch on top of the big Pyramid. The whole party returned afterwards to Mena House Hotel and had dinner there.

div.head: Institution for the Blind at Zeitoun.
div.p: It may interest many of our readers to know that the concert given in aid of the above institution at Shepheard's Hotel on the 21st March last was a financial success. We have been favoured with a oopy of the report of the committee from which we gather that the total receipts were P.T. 7,500 and the expenses P.T. 1,118, leaving a balance of P.T. 6,382, which amount has been duly handed over to the president of the committee of the institution, who, in acknowledging the receipt of the cheque, thanks the promoters, the artistes, and all who gave their services, for their very great kindness in so substantially aiding a most deserving charity.

div.head: Murder Will Out.
div.p: On the 25th of last month, on the occasion of the holding of the weekly market at El Ham- mam, a murder was committed at some dis- tance from that village, a Bedeuin having been found shot in the head. The police took the matter in hand, but until yesterday no trace of the murderer could be found. Yesterday was again the market day and a polioe officer belonging to the Mariout district who was on duty there received information to the effect that the murderer, a Bedouin like his victim, was to be found at Sidi Gaber. He at once proceeded by train in company with his informant, who pointed the man out near Sidi Gaber caraool. The murderer was thereupon arrested and in bis possession was found a new revolver with six chambers loaded, besides twelve rounds of ammunation. It appears that the man, knowing his viotim to possess a large sum of money, had followed him after the fair and, taking the opportunity of his being asleep in a field, had shot him through the head, afterwards taking a sum of about £70 off the body.

div.head: Spend your Holidays at Mena,
div.p: The management of Mena House Hotel has arranged" special terms for residents of Cairo, Alexandria, and country from the 10th of April to the 10th of May. [Advt.]

div.head: GERMANY,TURKEY, AND EGYPT. THE SULTAN AND TA BAH. HOW TO REOPEN THE EGYPTIAN QUESTION.
div.p: The "Daily Telegraph's" Correspondent at Constantinople says that well-informed Turk- ish circles attribute the Saltan's obstinancy over the Tabah affair to the suggestions of Germany, who is trying to persuade him to ask for the arbitration of The Hague Tribunal, thus reopening the whole Egyptian question, with a prospect of the ultimate recovery of the province.

Our contemporary "Al Mokattam" states that Turkish poets are now established all along the line from Gaza to Akaba and are stopping caravans on the frontier. Our contemporary adds that a number of traders and Bedouins have been robbed by these warriors.

div.head: MARCH TRADE RETURNS.
div.p: The trade returns for. March show increases exceeding 4 1/4 millions in imports and 3 1/2 in exports.

div.head: ANOTHER DEATH-DEALING WEAPON.
div.p: The "Echo de Paris"to-day reports the dis-covery of a marvellous invention of a quick- firing gun by an Artillery officer, which is capable of firing 600 shots a minute. The bullets, instead of being concentrated in one direction, are distributed over a radius of 160 degrees.

div.head: AMERICAN MINERS PROPOSE ARBITRATION.
div.p: The "Times" Correspondent at New York states that the coal miners have proposed arbi-tration. They are taking this step, it is said, in view of the great public interests which are involved.

div.head: GHARBIEH LAND COMPANY.
div.p: We bear that the emission of shares of this new company has been a great success, being covered more than three times over.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES.
div.p: MM. Herschitz and Roux de Vence have now entered on their functions as co syndics. The Parquet is at present busily engaged in examining the records of the Sucreries.

div.head: THE CRONIER BILLS.
div.p: A meeting of the shareholders of the Orleans Railway Company was held in Paris last week, when the question of the Cronier bills was discussed. It was unanimously acknowledged that the Board of Directors did not act against the statutes by discounting there bills with the reserve funds of the company, although it was admitted that the operation was attended with disastrous results. At the meeting of the Seciete Generale, held the same day, the Cronier bills were also mentioned; but before the question could be developed, the chairman announced that the managing director of the Société Generale had already resigned the directorship of the unfortunate Egyptian Sugar Refineries, as well as of other ventures, and would in future devote himself exclusively to the steadily-increasing affairs of the bank.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Sailor Prince, from Antwerp and London, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on Saturday, and is due at Alex-andria on Wednesday morning next.
Anglo-American Nile Steamers AND * HOTEL COMPANY- River Transport of Goods between Alexandria and Cairo. THREE SAILINGS A-WEEK. Agents at Alexandria

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: PRINCE OF WALES' PROMISE.
PROBABLE VISIT TO LONDON.

H. H. the Khedive has fixed his departure from Cairo for Alexandria for Monday, the 30th inst. The usual reception previous to his leaving the Capital will be held on either Thursday, the 26th, or Saturday, the 28th instant. We understand that his Highness has invit-ed T.R.H. the Prince and Princess of Wales to pay Egypt another and a longer visit at some future time, which invitation the Royal couple accepted. It is rumoured that the Khedive will in all probability pay a visit to London this summer at the invitation of his Royal visitors.

div.head: KHEDIVE ENTERTAINS THB ARCHDUKE
div.p: On Friday last the Khedive gave a small afternoon party at Koubbeh, the guests being T.R.H. the Archduke Joseph and the Arch- duchess Augusta, the Archduke's Chamberlain and physician, and the lady-in-waiting of the Archduchess, Count Koziebrodski, the Austro- Hungarian Minister, General Thurneyssen Pacha, A.D.C., and Mme Baltazzi Stockan and her daughter, in all, with the Khedive, 10 persons. The party first drove round the stables and admired the Khedive's fine stud, then drove over to the fields to watch the horses eating bersim, and subsequently proceeded to Monstourouh, the other pro-perty of the Khedive, close to Koub- beh, where tea bad been prepared. Afterwards the Khedive accompanied his guests back to Koubbeh. It was a delightful afternoon, and on Saturday morning, when General Thurneyssen Pacha went to the station to see the Archduke off on behalf of the Khedive, the Archduke and Archduchess asked him to present the expression of their thankfulness to the Khecfive for the pleasant afternoon they had passed with him. The Khedive has made a gift of a thoroughbred Arab to the Archduchess.

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: Ibrahim Pasha Fathy's report on the pilgrimage will in all probability be published in the near future. The Hag has been a thorough success from every point of view—save that of some of the Bedonins—and not a single Egyptian pilgrim, soldier or official, has fallen a victim to the lawless tribes of the Hedjaz.

div.head: THE HEDJAZ RAILWAY.
div.p: We bear that the Ottoman authorities are pushing this railway forward as rapidly as pos sible S. of Qala' at Medawara towards Tebonk. The line will pass through Tebouk and Qala" at El Akbdar and will then enter a depression with easy gradients and free from any great engineering difficulties till Medina is reached. Herr Meissner, the able German engineer, to whom the construction of the line is mainly due, has been recently on a visit to railhead

div.head: PORT SUDAN AND KHARTOUM WATER SUPPLY.
div.p: Some time ago the Artesian Boring and Prospecting Company received from the Sudan Government the contract for the installation of water supplies by means of artesian wells to the towns of Khartoum and Port Sudan. With regard to the latter place they have just received a telegram . from their residing engineer informing them that up-to-date their steam-driven "Express Boring'' plant has reached a depth of 400 feet with a first borehole, and that already this artesian well is able to supply a certain quantity of fresh water to the inhabitants of Port Sadan. There seems to be no doubt that the source of the water comes from the mountains situated in the neighbourhood of the town, as the level of the water in the bore-well rises to a considerable height above the sea level If, how. ever, the output is not sufficient further borings are intended to be made in order to ensure all the necessary supply of water which may eventually be required. With regard to Khartoum, the company's installation for the supply of fresh water to the whole. town, also by means of artesian wells, is on the point of being finished, by means of wells driven to a depth between 250 and 350 feet. In the course of the works the company have encountered stratas of excellent Nubian sandstone, which will ensure a supply of the best pare water.
ALEXANDRIA BONDED WAREHOUSE CO. LTD

div.head: A CHAPTER OF ACCIDENTS.
div.p: A native boy, while playing with some other boys in the Mohatrem Bey quarter yesterday, was run over by a passing cart and succumbed a few hours afterwards to bis injuries. A native youth of 17 was run overby a tram- car yesterday on the Mex line, while he was attempting to cross the rails. He was promptly taken to hospital, bat expired a short time after wards. Some natives who were witnesses of the accident attacked the driver and conductor of the tram and beat them unmercifully, causing them severe injuries. A native, aged 65 years, was bathing in the sea yesterday near the Alexandria Slaughterhouse, when he was carried out of his depth by the waves and was drowned. His body was recovered.

div.head: GREEK INDEPENDENCE DAY.
HELLENIC MUNIFICENCE. INTERESTING CEREMONY.
div.p: The celebration of the anniversary of the declaration of Greek independence on Saturday last will long be remembered by the Greek oolony at Alexandria, for the occasion was made use of for laying the foundation-stone of an institution which is destined to be one of the finest educational establishments in Egypt. The former president of the Hellenic com-munity of Alexandria, the late Mr. Constantino Salvago, left a bequest in bis will for the purpose of founding a polytechnic here. After his death the bequest was largely increased by the generosity of Mr. Salvago's widow and two sons. A large plot of land was bought ourside Rosetta-gate, in front of the cemeteries, and yesterday afternoon the foun-dation stone of the institution was laid by Mrs. Argentina Michel Salvago, in the presence of a great concourse of members of the Greek colony and representatives of the other European colonies.

A large tent was set up for the occasion, where a sumptuous buffet was prepared. At 4.30 o'olock the ceremony began with a thanksgiving service, conducted by the Greek Orthodox Patriarch'Photius I., assisted by all his clergy. The Patriarch, at the conclusion of the service, invoked the blessing of the Most High on the new school by sprinkling holy water, and finished an eloquent harangue with an account of the many acts of generosity by which the Greek colony of Alexandria had benefited owing to the munificence of its wealthy members.

After the Patriarch Mr. Paleologos Georgiou, the headmaster of the Hellenic community's sohools, read from a parchment document the formal bequest of the donors, which was afterwards signed by Photius I, Mohamed Bey Hafez, Acting Governor of Alexandria, Mr. N. Scotidis, Hellenic Consul-General, Mr. E. B. Gould, H.B.M.'s Consol General for the City and Port of Alexandria, Schiess Pacha, Vice-President of the Alexandria Municipality, Chataway Bey, Administrator of the Alexandria Municipality, Mr. Emmanuel Benachi and Mr. Michael Sinadino, the President and Vice-President of the Hellenic community, Messrs. Michael and Steffy Salvago, Mrs. Constantino Salvago, and Mrs Argentina Miohel Salvago. The parchment was looked in a metal tube and placed in the orifice of the foundation-stone together with a copy of thp "Egyptian Gazette" and the "Harmonia" of the day's date, besides some specimens of oar- rent Egyptian coins. Mrs. Argentina Michel Salvago then advanced and, after christening the stone with the contents of two bottles of champagne, received a beauti- fnlly-chased silver trowel, a mallet, and a hammer, presented by the well-known Italian engineer, Signor Diamanti, and then proceeded to declare the stone "well and truly laid."

A buffalo was then brought forward and sacrificed on the foundation-stone. The beast was afterwards cat up and its flesh distributed to the poor. The fine band of the Alexandria Hellenic community played meanwhile a choice selection of music, and the stone was lowered into its position amidst the acclamations of the assembled multitude. The President of the Hellenic commnnity, Mr. Emmanuel Benachi, then made an eloquent speech wherein he called to mind the good deeds of the benefactors of the Greek colony of Alexandria, such as the late George Averoff and the late Constantine Salvago, whose noble example was to-day being followed by the surviving members of the family of his predecessor, the late president of the community. Mr. Benschi then declared that the Hellenic colony was shortly to benefit by another act of generosity, for Mr. George Zervudaohi has decided to build at his own expense a Normal College here.

The speaker went on to announce that be would follow Mr. Zervndachi's example by endowing the Hellenio oolony with an orphanage. At these unexpected announcements there was a great outburst of cheering and the crowd rent the air with their acclamations of pleasure at these acts of generosity.

Mr. N. Scotidis, Hellenic Consul-General at Alexandria, then prononnoed a brilliant speech, thanking the donors of these splendid gifts in the name of the Greeks of Alexandria. He .begged the wealthy members of his race to follow these magnifioent precedents, and to set an example of generosity and public spirit whereby the Hellenic commnnity throughout Egypt would ever march in the van of progress.

Mr. Miohel Salvago thanked all the speakers on behalf of his mother, his brother, and himself, declaring that be was merely obeying the orders given by his late father in his will, and be hoped that he and his family wonld hereafter follow the example set by his father in doing other works for the good of his compatriots in Egypt's commercial capital.

After another explosion of cheering the Pat-riarch Photius I., accompanied by the head master of the Hellenic community's schools, walked among the long files of pupils of the schools, who formed a cordon between the speakers and guests and the crowd. His Beatitude addressed words of enoonragement and commendation to the youths, urging them to work bard and follow in the path of virtue. The buffet was then thrown open and a handsome repast was partaken of and the memorable ceremony came to an end.

Afterwards a procession was formed of the pupils, beaded by their band, mi the headmaster and professional staff, who went to the Greek quarter and played a selection of music outside the houses of Messrs. Benachi, Sinadino, Salvago, and Zervodaohi.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: SATURDAY'S DECISIONS. LAKE MENZALEH TAXES ABOLISHED.

Among the decisions of the Council of Ministers held on Saturday afternoon are the following Mr. Kirkwood James is appointed to study a project for the drainage of Cairo. A new railway station is to be built at Halk El Gamal on the Delta Light Railway, between Atfeh and Edfina. The draft decree dealing with the giving of information to the provincial authorities on. the appearance of cotton worm in any locality, is approved. A new company known as the Express Nile Steamer Company is sanctioned. A newmafran, known as the Mafran Benshir, is to be constructed at Minieh. The Council also approved of the abolition of taxes formerly imposed on boats on Lake Menzaleh.

div.head: THREATENED BARBERS' STRIKE.
div.p: The Unione Internazionale dei Parruchieri Lavoranti of Cairo held a meeting on Friday evening at the Brasserie Fleisch, when some 60 members of the union were present. It was unanimously decided to demand from the masters the closing of their shops entirely on Sunday daring the summer months, from the 1st May to the 30th September, and to fix the Working hours during week-days from 7.30 a.m. to 8.30 p.m., with an interval of two hours in the middle of the day for meals, instead of one hour and a half, as at present Should the masters not concede these concessions in full by to-day at the latest, the barbers intend going on strike. It is expected that a compromise will be arrived at when the committee of the union go round this morning for the answers of the masters.

div.head: GREEK INDEPENDENCE DAY.
div.p: Satarday being the 85th anniversary of the declaration of Greek independence the diplomatic agencies and consulates in Cairo flew their respective flags. A Thanksgiving Service, which was very largely attended, was held at the Gre'k Orthodox Hameiwi Cathedral at 10 a.m. The personnel of the Greek Diplomatic Agency and Consulate and all the notables of the colony attended the service, over which the Patriarch presided. This service, which lasted an hour, was followed by a reception at the Greek Agency. In the evening a meeting was held at the Greek Club, where M. Boukavalaa delivered an eloquent and a patriotic address to an enthusiastic audience.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: H.H. the Khedivab-Mother is leaving Alexandria on Wednesday by the 8. 8. Prince Abbas for Costantinople.
The Khedive gave andienos to Lord Cromer | at Abdeen Palace this morning,
It is now stated that the Kaiser bas not abandoned his Mediterranesu trip. He will travel by the Hamburg-American liner Ham. burg, which is being fitted op as a royal yacht.
H. E. Mustapha Pacha Ibady, the now Governor of Alexandria, is expected to arrive from Cairo this afternoon. He will take ap his new duties at the Gouvernorat to-morrow.

The Barl and Countess of Carnarvon are due at Port Said from Ceylon shortly. They were accompanied on their travels in Colombo by the Countess of Lsnesborough, and are expected back in London shortly after Baster. The Countess of Lanesborough, who was not very well when sbe left Bagland, has benefited very muoh by the trip,
Baron Max von Oppenheim is shortly lear |ing Egypt for Syria on a scientific mission.
Judge and Mrs. Veroamer are velebrating the diamond marriage of their parente, Mr. and Mrg Charles Veroamer, by an "At Home" on the 15th inst., at the New Khedivial Hotel, Alexandria
The condition of M. Polis Suares gives rise to some anxiety. The inflammation of the | langs bas apparently subsided but the heart weakness is unfortunately pronounced.
Baron and Baroness von Pitner gave two banquets at the Carlton Hotel on Saturday and Sunday in bonour of Rear-Admiral von Jedios.
General and Mrs. Frederic Lance arrived at the Carlton Hotel to-day and leave for Burope on Thursday
Sir George and Lady Cooper, who have been spending a few days in Italy and Paris after their trip up the Nile, returned home last week.
Sir James Blyth and the Hon. Harry Law son have aleo arrived in London from Bgypt. Mr. Lawson is to remain the Conservative candidata for Mile End.
The Pilgrims are giving a banquet in London on May 99 in honour of the Right Rev. Bishop Potter, D.D., Bishop of New York and president of the Pilgrims of America.
The funeral of the late Governor of the National Bank of Egypt did not take place as originally arranged on Saturday week, but was anavoidably postponed until last Monday
The death took place at Alexandria on Saturday, at the age of 78 years, of M. Bishara Bassili.
Capt. H. B. Kennedy, 1st King's Royal Rifle Corps, Major A. H. Ratherford and 2nd-Lieut. C. C. A. Cooper, 1st Royal Dublin Fasiliera, bava been granted leave of absence.
Lient. T. 8. Dimiok, Inspector of Army Sobools in Egypt, Malta, sto., has arrived in Alexandria.

Dr. Ronald Kickness, who acted as medioal officer of the Anglo-American Line steamer Victoria during the past season, is returning to England by the P. & 0. Sands, leaving Port Saïd to-day. He is a brother of Mr. Kirkness of the State Railways.

The living of Deene, Stamford, has been offered, on behalf of the Countess of Cardigan, to the Ven. Archdeacon Harris, Chaplain to the King and to the Plest, by whom it has been accepted. The Archdeacon is the possessor of the Egyptian Medal, the Alexandria olasp, and the Khedive's bronzg star, 1882.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries Et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le taux de l'exompete libre a Londres vient d'etre eleve de 1/8 a 3 pour cent. Hier, au Stock Exchange, le Consolide anglais a resctionne de 1/8 a 91. L'Unifiee, la Naitonal Bank et l'Agricole sont restees invaries. La Daira a regagne 1/8 a 3/8. A Paris, l'action Credit Foncier Egyptien est demeuree inchangee a 793. La Banque d'Athenes a reagi de 1 franc a 156.

Notre marche des valeurs a montre, ce matin, beancoup d'animation aur quelques valeurs notamment sur les Delta Land, les Enterprises Immobilieres et Travaux, les Hooker et les Markets. Les transactions pratiquees sur ces titres ont ete nombreuses et impertantes.

Le compartiment des Banques a ete quelque peu llourd. Delaissee, la National a flechi a 27 1/8. L'Agricole, quioique plus active, n'en est past moins revenue a 10 1/4. Le Comptoir Financier eat reste a 8 1/4. Les journaux d'Alexandria rapportent que cette Societe, a'etant occupee de constituer le syndicat de garantie d'une Compagnie de navigation en formation sous le nom de "The Egyptian and Smyrna Steam Navigation CO.," a obtenn 2,500 parts de fondation a titre de commission.
L'action Credit Foncier a cloture a 797 et l'obligation a lots 1886 a 337-338; la Daira entre 18 et 18 1/16.

Comme hier, il y a eu un tres bon mouvement sur les sotions Entreprises Immboilieres et Travaux, qui ont cloture a 4 9/16 apres avoir atteint 4 21/32. La part defondateur a tait L.E. 22 ; par auite de es prochaine subdivision en coupures de 25, elle a ete inscrite des aujourd'hui au tableau official a P.E. 85. Il faut s'attendre a ades cours beaucoup plus eleves que ce prix nominal.
LEs Omnibus du Caire ont remonte a 34 1/2. La Khedivial Maile ete traitee entre 41 et 40 sh.
L'action Agricole du Nil a fair 287; la part de fondateur 9 7/8. Les dividendes Tramways d'Alexandrie ont hausre a 346.
Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Nungovich ont progresse a 18 5/8. Les Upper Egypt sont revenus a 5 1/4.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les honneurs de la seance ont ete, aujourd'hui encore, pour les Delta Land, quni ont avance a 4 7/16. Les Hooker ont ete echanges a 1 5/16--1/4/ Les New Egyptian ont coture a 33 sh. 9. Les Egyptian Constructions ont ete ramenees a 1 1/2. En bonne tendance, les Markets ont avance a 25 sh. 9-26.

Pour completer les renseignements que nous avons donnes hier sur les Egyptian Markets, il nous faur exposer les raisons de la plus-value extraordinaire acquise par les terrains dans laqulle la Societe est interessee dans toute l'Egypte.

Ces terrains, sur lesquels la Societe a establises marches etaient situes hors des villes ; or, par le fiar de l'extension prise par celles-ci, ils se trouvent actuellement soit pres du centre, soit aux abords immediats des cites, ce qui a enormement a augmente leur valeur.

A Benha, par exemple, la Compagnie a deja sobete un terrain "extra muros" pour etablir son marche. L'ancien sera loti et vendu a des conditions tres avantageuese. Il en sera de meme pour les terrains ou les marches sont etablis dans les autres villes importantes de l'interieur.
On concoit des lors les benefices considerables que la Societe est appele a realiser de ce chef.

Scotland beat England by 2 goals to 1 in Dis Association Football match played to-day.
(Reuter)

div.head:
VESUVIUS' ALARMING ACTIVITY.
FLIGHT OF VILLAGERS.
CONSTANT'EXPLOSIONS.
FEARED LOSS OF LIFE

div.p: The Prefect of Naples is sending troops and conveyances to remove the panic-stricken villa­gers.
The eruption of Vesuvine continues to cause alarm.
The village of Boscotrecase is encircled by lava ; the inhabitants are decamping. (R.)

The eruption of Vesuvius is assuming extraordiuary proportions; A cone collapsed on the Pompei side and a new crater has opened on the opposite side. Constant explosions are taking place from the principal crater, which is vomited red hot rocks to a height of 3,000- feet. Naples is crowded with refugees. The houses have been shaken and many of the inhabitants collected in the squares yesterday night, r

The Vesuvius Observatory and Railway have been destroyed, hot the scientists escaped in time. Boscotrecase has been completely abandoned and the inhabitants of Torre Anuunziata are leaving. Avellino and Benevento, which are situated at 20 and 83 miles respectively from Vesuvius, are plunged in darkness. 8howers of ashes have been tailing since yesterday night. Hoases at San Giuseppe have been wrecked It is feared that some lives have been lost (B.)
The eruption of Vesuvius is becoming more alarmin' ^very day. The inhabitants of the neighboring villages are leaving their homes.
(Haw)

div.head:
PREMIER AND SOUTH AFRICA.
THE GOVERNMENT'S AIM.

div.p: Sir H. Campbell Bannerman complained of attacks on the Government with reference to South Africa, where the Government aimed at the maintenance of British supremacy with equal rights for all whites.
He hoped that the Algeoiras settlement would lead to a diminution of the weight of military burdens of nations, wherein Britain could lead the way. (Better)

div.head:
ESCAPE OF BAMBAATA.
TROOPS IN PURSUIT

div.p: Bambaata has escaped into Zuloland pursued by the troops of Colonel Leuchars. The loyal natives are co operating. (Reuter)
The Commissioners have left South African
(Reuter.)

div.head:
THE NAVY.
NEVER IN BETTER CONDITION.

div.p: At the Fishmongers' Company's banquet to the Ministers, Lord Tweedmouth said that the Navy was never so well equipped, officered, manned, and ready to fight. (Reuter.)

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON IN SIND.
div.p: (Plot the "Times of Indu").
Endeavours to introduce foreign varieties of
cotton into this country have hitherto proved
generally unsuccessful. If in some exceptional
circumstances they did well at the first sowing,
they rapidly deteriorated and the experiments
proved to be failures. In most cases, however,
they did not grow at all. So uniform, indeed,
has been the failure of efforts to introduce new
varieties of cotton that the attempt had been
declared practically hopeless, and hybridization
among the indigenous varieties was Supposed
to offer the only prospect of improvement in
the crop. It is especially gratifying, therefore,
to learn from the report of the Bombay Department of Agriculture that the cultivation
of Egyptian cotton in Sind has fairly passed
the stage of experiment; and may be expected,
if it continues as well as it has done during the
last two years, to give an outturn of not less
than 100,000 balos in the course of a few years.
The experiment was first made in the year
before last of sowing Egyptian cotton in the
spring so as to enable it to mature before the
advent of the winter frosts. Last year the
Deputy Director obtained and distributed ten
tons of Egyptian seed to select zemindars on
the Jamrao Canal An area of about 1,506
acres was sown with the seed. The yield has
been very satisfactory, both in quality and in
staple, and the zemindars are said to
anxious to extend its cultivation on a large
scale. As it is probable that this seed may
retain its superiority of staple if Egyptian
methods are closely followed, it is proposed to
restrict the cultivation to those zemindars who
undertake to sow it under supervision and
whose lands can be practically supervised. No
signs of deterioration have been observed in
the oropof theseoond year, and it is worthy
of note that while the local indigenous variety
suffered severely from attacks of bollwornr the
imported Egyptian variety were almost immune. The two Egyptians that have proved
most successful so far are the Abbassi aud the
Mitaffiffi. Of the two the former is the more
valuable and arrangements have therefore
been made to export the seed of the Mitaffiffi
grown this year, aud to import a sufficient
consignment of Abbassi seed from Egypt. The
successful introduction of Egyptian cotton
means so much to the mill industry that the
results of the current year will be watched with
the greatest expectation.

div.head: ARMY ARD NAVY
div.p: On the 6th June next, Brevet-Colonel S. G. Bird, D.8.O., Royal Dublin Fusiliers, will vacate the command of the 1st Battalion in Egypt, to the regret of all ranks. Colonel Bird got his first commission in the old 102nd Royal Madras Fusiliers—now the'1st Battalion of the gallaqt "Dabs"—in 1874, was promoted captain in 1881, major in 1892, and lieutenant-oolonel in June, 1902. He was adjutant of a militia battalion from 1886 to 1889, and also of the Ceylon Volunteer Light Infantry from 1889 till 1894. He was with the Dublins in the South African War, including the opening action of the campaign at Talana Hill; Lombard's Kop; the operations in the Orange Free State, operations in the Transvaal, west of Pretoria; and for some time he was Commandant at Krugersdorp (mentioned twice in despatches, D.S.O., Qaeen*8 medal with four clasps, King's medal with two clasps). It if anticipated that Major and Brevet-Lieutenant-Colonel A. W. Gordon, second in command of the 2nd Batt. Buttevant, will get the step; Major A' H.Rutherford will become second-in-command ofthe let Battalion, and the majority will go to Captain R. A. Booth, 2nd Battalion.
Captain W. N. Gordon, Royal Garrison Artillery, has been transferred Lorn No. 2 Company, Cairo, to No. 55 Company, Gibraltar.

Major T. M'Cullooh, Major J. G. M'Naught, and Major J.C. Weir. Roy*l Army Medical Corps, serving at the War Offioe, Edinburgh and London respectively, have been selected to go on the Commission which is to enquire into the Mediterranean Fever, which has auoh baneful effects on our naval and military forces in that water.'

It is persistently rumoured that Mr. Haldane intends to reduce the Army by 20,000 men in the near future, despite the official utterances on the 8ubjeot. "More brains" and "smaller battalions" is to be the new article of faith in Pali Mall if rumour is to be trusted. The Service members of the House are much exercised over the contemplated redaction of one little Army, and the now strong Labour Party, however opposed to militarism and taxation, are averse to anything that would turn 20,000 men into the already crowded labour market It is said that Mr. Haldane has made good progress amongst the members of the Army Connoil in favour of his scheme.

There is no better-known "salt" than Captain John A. Take, who has been selected for the command of the cruiser Monmouth, which will be commissioned next week toreplace the Andromeda on the China Station. Captain Tuke, who has served on the blue in all parts of the world, joined the Queen's Navy in July, 1870, was promoted lieutenant in 1881, commander in 1895, and captain on the last day of 1901. He was a sub-lieutenant on the Pioneer in the Niger Expedition of 18.79, and was with the expedition to the oapital of the Emir of Nussa, and participated in the operations round and the bombardment of the town of Nussa (mentioned in despatches); was lieutenant in the Northum- berland during the Egyptian War of 1882 (medal, and the Khedive's star). He held the appointment of Master of the Fleet for the Coronation Naval Review, 1902. He is.no stranger to the China Station, having been commander and navigating officer of the battle- ship Centurion, flagship o? Sir E. H. Seymour, K. C. B., when he oommauded the station, 1898-1901. Latterly Captain Take was in oommand of the gunnery ship Undaunted, and the Theseus, tender to the gunnery ship Cambridge, Devonport.

The cruiser Hyaointh, ex-flagship of the East Indies Squadron, which is on the passage home from the East, will undergo an extensive refit at Devonport before she again hoists the pennant. The sum of £28,635 will b& expend- ed on her, and some alterations will be made in her armament. The Hyacinth was commissioned as flagship of the squadron on the Sflst July, 1902, to relieve her sister cruiser Highflyer. Since going to the East, the Hyacinth's crew took part in the operations against the Mad Mullah in Somaliland, andfrom her was landed a party which captured Illig just two years ago.
The Yankees are going to try to knockout the Dreadnought by expending £2,000,000 on battleship of the "lick-creation" type,

The Egyptian State Railways hereby givea notice to the public that the Administration requires 40 pupils—who will be trained for the Traffio aervioe with a view to their being ap­pointed aa assistant gaarda in Upper or Lower Egypt. Competitive examination for the ad­mission of pnpils to fill these vacancies will be held on and after the 21st April proximo, before a Special Commission at Cairo station.
Candidates mast fulfil the following con­ditions :—
1st—They mnat be of Egyptian nationality;
2nd -They must be of good character ;
3rd -They mnat have a fair knowledge of a European language (English or French) ;
4th -They must be medically fit ter Railway service ;
5th They mnat be between the age of 20 and 25 years ;
7th—Pupils will receive P.T. 8 per day each during the period allowed for training on trains working and will receive higher pay when they have passed a aatiafaotory examination.
Candidates deairona of attending the above examination, are required to send their names
the Traffio Manager, before 15th April.

Candidates presenting themaelve. at the place of examination will first of all be required to undergo an examination as to medical fit­ness, and not be allowed to proceed further with the examination unless they qoalify in thia.
The 40 candidates, who in the opinion of the Board of Examination are the best fitted as regards oharaoter and both physical and mental acquirements, will be appointed.
